results.title: St Kilda: the lonely islands
results.creator_credit: Films of Scotland and Christopher Mylne
results.brief_description: An evocation of the sense of timelessness which impresses itself on a visitor to this island in the Outer Hebrides. Depicts the unique fauna, and breathtaking beauty of the place, and shows the work of conservationists on the island.
results.description: An evocation of the sense of timelessness which impresses itself on a visitor to this island in the Outer Hebrides. Depicts the unique fauna, and breathtaking beauty of the place, and shows the work of conservationists on the island.

results.title: St Barbe of the trees
results.creator_credit: M B Oldfield and Sons and Barrie Oldfield
results.brief_description: Presents 92 year-old Richard St Barbe Baker, the man who founded the international movement “Men of the Trees” in 1922, talking about trees: their life-giving qualities, the threats to them from disease and overfelling; and the need to plant for our lives. The first half of the film is scientific in approach while the second half becomes more lyrical with St Barbe reciting his favourite tree poems.

results.title: St Albans: an ethnic programme
results.creator_credit: Canberra. College of Advanced Education. Media Centre and Ian Hart
results.brief_description: St Albans is a multilingual, multicultural community where 85% of the population are migrants from non-English speaking countries. St Albans East Primary School, with a school’s commission grant, employ parents in a program to increase the children’s awareness of community languages and culture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Canberra. College of Advanced Education. Media Centre and Ian Hart

results.title: Squizzy Taylor
results.creator_credit: Roger Simpson, Roger Le Mesurier and Kevin Dobson
results.brief_description: Set in the 1920’s, in Melbourne, and covering the life and experiences of the enterprising and notorious criminal Squizzy Taylor. Stars Jackie Weaver, Alan Cassell and David Atkins.

results.title: Squirrel on my shoulder and Brockside
results.brief_description: Squirrel on my shoulder, narrated by Sir David Attenborough, tells the story of Sammy, an orphaned baby Grey Squirrel which was raised by a cat as one of her kittens, and eventually released back into the wild. “Brockside”, presented by Simon King, looks at the tenuous life of the urban Badger, living off its human neighbours as urban devlopment enchroaches on the lands they have traditionally occupied.

results.title: Squirrel-cage rotor principles
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Electrical work: electrical machinery”.
Laws of magnetism and induced electromagnetic fields.; electric flow in squirrel-cage rotor setting up magnetic poles which create torque; construction of squirrel-cage rotors.

results.title: Squinka
results.brief_description: A film about the power a Squinka medallion has over a group of young people and how it becomes a mnemonic for the group as they search for jobs. After some argument they exchange their individual interpretations of what Squinka means. They discuss how Squinka can be used to guide individual careers.

results.title: Squeak the squirrel
results.creator_credit: Churchill-Wexler Film Productions and Lester F. Beck
results.brief_description: A baby squirrel is used in experiments to show how animals learn. He soon learns not to be afraid of people, finds how to get nuts out of glass tubes and out of boxes. He stuffs them in his cheek pouches and scurries off to hoard them in his nest.
